column4: Hey, quick (and easy) question...  If Ubuntu freezes up on me, how do I fix it?  IOW, what's the Task Manager equivalent?
So, yeah...  dead app (I guess)
CompizConfig Settings Manager

first you'd need to find the reason for the lockup. Can you still switch to a console with CTRL-ALT-F1? can you login from outside via ssh? does the num lock key change the LED on your keyboard? or is the machine _really_ frozen? check the log files in /var/log/syslog etc
switch to console, that is.
then your Ubuntu didnt freeze on you, but perhaps Gnome. Switch back to Gnome (ALT-F7) and try ALT-F1 - does the top menu get selected?
Yes, top menu is selected.
please describe, what exactly froze

I was playing with one of the modules in CompizConfig Settings Manager -- Freely Transformable Windows, to be exact.  When I enabled one of the features, it appeared to froze.  Mouse wouldn't do anything except move around on screen.  It's locked in a closed-hand position, but I'm unable to click on anything.
i see. If you can't kill the program due to a confused mouse, you can start a terminal via keyboard - ALT-F1 and enter "xkill" - then click the window, that is frozen. Tell me, if that worked.
ALT-F2 sorry
I don't know if I can kill it.  What's the best way to try to do that?
deselect the menu with ESC
Thanks.  Was trying everything (except that, of course)
Not looking good.  xkill doesn't appear to do anything.

usually you get an x shaped mouse cursor. in your case, the cursor might not show, but still work. "try" to aim at the frozen window and do a left click. If that wont do, i can suggest another approach.
Hmmm, looks like I can interact with the application via the keyboard, so it's just the mouse that's locked up.
lets kill the X server. Do you have important data not yet saved in any window?

the "cool" way would to just kill the damaged process. For this you would switch to the console and use the ps command to find the PID and then use kill. The "simple" way is to brutally kill (restart) X - which can be done with ALT-SysRq(Print)-K - what shall it be?
you should learn the "cool" method soon - its not really hard and makes more sense in many situations. Ask, if you wanna try it.
Alright, that did the trick for now.  I'll make a note of the ps command and make sure to study up.
i usually do: ps -A | grep WHATISEARCHFOR
